sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: (Riſes and appears.) Oh, dear Sir— (ſimpering.)

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: By the lord, this is my little pitcher again.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: (Unſeen, whips out of the door, and taps him on the ſhoulder.) Mr. Thomas!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: A'n't you aſhamed of yourſelf, Kitty Barleycorn?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Come, my dear creatures, you muſtn't—

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Well, I know we muſtn't—

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: What, Ma'am? Don't quarrel about me, zounds! I'm like a ſtately peacock between a pheaſant and a turkey hen.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: La! you're ſo wild—

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: But he's very merry, he! he! he!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Wild! merry! my whole life has been one frolic.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Ay, I dare ſay, when you were a boy—

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Such diverſions! altering the numbers of doors to puzzle the poſtman, at Chriſtmas in a ſtage coach changing the directions of geeſe, hares, and turkeys, with a bit of chalk and charcoal making a whole room of family portraits ſquint down upon every body.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: I vow you muſt not come and ſee our pictures.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: La! he's ſo pleaſant! Well, and ah, Mr. Tom!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: My ſweet creature, I came to hanſel the ſilver cup. Hey! a bottle of port and a roaſted orange! Ladies, I vow on the honour of a hermit, I'll treat you with a biſhop.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Toby! (calling.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Eh! where's this young dog my prentice, bad as my mad nephew. Waiter! my horſe.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Sir, you'll return to ſup at our houſe.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Fooliſh Dick Whimmy to have no dinner! plague of his gardens, in his ponds plenty of carp and tench, that nobody dare fling into a frying-pan; on his green ſlopes, neither graſs lamb nor aſparagus, and for flocks of geeſe and chickens, there a peacock ſtruts, or an eagle perches, that inſtead of any body eating him, by the Lord, looks as if he'd eat us. My dear, I'm going to Weymouth, cou'dn't you give one a ſnack.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh! our bill of fare, Sir, (going.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p:
(Stops her.) As fine a bill of fare as e'er I look'd on, (gazing) what diſh ſhall I chooſe—a white forehead, a brace of black eyes, garniſh'd with long
auburn eye-laſhes, two roſy cheeks, cherry lips, my deſert.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: A pity, Mr. Thomas, to diſguiſe his fine hair and delightful ſhape, in that long old beard and gown. La! Sir, what a choice hermit you'd make for Mr. Whimmy; you'd be a nice bald-headed buck, as Tom ſays.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: I a bald-headed buck! don't you ſee I wear my own hair, child?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: I've brew'd the biſhop. Eh! what old fellow—ſo ſmooth with Kitty—Sir, a word if you pleaſe, (twitches off Old Pranks's wig)—Zounds, my uncle! (runs off.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Stop that ſcoundrel, (runs after him.)

div.stage: Bell rings violently, Kitty runs into the houſe.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! my ſon Natty!

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Mamma! ſhe has me, but I won't be diſgrac'd, (aſide, and turns.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: My dear child, who could think of ſeeing you down here, (he turns from her, and walks.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Any buſineſs with me, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Why, my dear! Don't you know me, Natty?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Zounds, Ma'am, don't Natty me!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Won't you ſpeak to your mother?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Who are you talking to, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Look at me—my own child deny me, (puts her handkerchief to her eyes, and walks up.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: John, is that the young man you ſaw?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: (Looking at his watch.) I ſhall be late with my party, (going.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Stay, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: I'm nobody's boy, but my own man, he! he!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Seize him, (to John) Your name? (to Maggs.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: What of it?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: What it was yeſterday, and will be to-morrow.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Mind how he ſhuffles; do ye ſee it, John? Tell me your name to-morrow, (to Maggs.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Muſn't, becauſe of mamma. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You belong to Mr. Pranks.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Suppoſing ſo.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe you're my priſoner.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Me! for what!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You broke out of jail in Babylon, but we'll handcuff and ſend you to Dorcheſter.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Handcuff! Broke jail in Babylon! Ay! why ſurely they take me for Tom Pranks!—I'm not the perſon you want.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: I arreſt you.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: I'm not the man indeed, my friend.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Who anſwers for you? who knows you?

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Then I muſt own mother—let me go, this gentlewoman here is my honour'd mamma.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) A wicked wretch, firſt to deny, and now to own me in his diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Mrs. Maggs, be he your ſon?

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Oh! no, he's no ſon of mine.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Nay, my dear mamma.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Sir, don't mamma me; who are you talking to? (mimicking.)

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Ay! why ſure, ſweet mamma!—

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Stop; you ſee, my friend, it won't paſs. John, look he don't run away, while I read diſcription of his parſon, (takes out paper and reads) five feet eight inches tall, an expreſſive eye, pleaſing features, good complexion, fine teeth, ſhew your teeth, (to Maggs) a handſome countenance—

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: 'Pon my ſoul this deſcription's very much like me tho'.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Well-made, a genteel deportment; upon the whole, an elegant figure.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Amazing! what a picture of me!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing like the child indeed.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: You ſee it's you.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: No, it's ſuch another handſome fellow, but really not me.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Come, I arreſt you with a little tap, (trips up his heels) hold his legs, Jahn, that he mayn't kick I.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Damn'd uncivil this!

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: I can't bear to ſee him treated ſo—let the child go, you fellows!

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Yes, the child ſhall go—to priſon.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: You're wrong, he's my ſon.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: And juſt now you ſaid—Ay, I ſee how 'tis, Meaſter Butler told me that Mrs. Maggs locks herſelf in her own room, and there drinks the preſarved apricocks—Jahn don't mind, Madam Maggs is ſo fond of talking ſhe'll ſay any thing—bring him along.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Sir, gentlemen conſtables! mamma! kind country juſtices! mother! (Toby holding him by the head, and John by the legs, they drag him off.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Why, you horrid villains, you ſhall not!—my child!

div.head: SCENE III. The Gardens. Statues thrown down, and broken fragments lying about; ſhrubs and plants, as pulled up.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p:
I vill complete the good work; lay there accurſed, (throws it down on a heap) and I vill pulls
up thy groves, and I vill root thee out of the land, (pulls plants out of pots, and flings them about.)

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Sir, your dinner's waiting. (Aſide) Dang my buttons! here's a fine kick-up! what raſcal cou'd have got in here—ſome one that owes the 'ſquire a grudge.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I've been doing of the job, 'twas all pagan wanity.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: So it was, Sir, and you were right to capſize it.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh! father, I ſhall go diſtracted; I'm ſure it's my belov'd Tom that they're taking pris'ner to Dorcheſter, yet ſo cruel not to let me ſee him.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: I've left the priſoner in ſafe cuſtody with Jahn Grum.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Then I brings him up to town, and lodges him with the Marſhal.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh heaven! tell me, Toby, is it the hermit?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: It is he.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: 'Tis not tho'—why you're as bad as Mrs. Maggs, who juſt now ſaid he was her ſon, and he wasn't her ſon—there's diſcription of his perſon, (gives Kitty a a paper.)

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: (Reading with emotion.) Handſome, elegant, fine teeth, expreſſive eye—'tis he! you hard-hearted creature—but I'll releaſe my own true love, tho' I beg my bread for it.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Ay now, ſhe too has been drinking apricocks.—Be's I to lay the cloth for you in the two-bedded room, (to Barebones.)

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I loves to eat in a parlour.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Why we wiſh to reſarve that for—

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Parlour! than, Sir, ſhan't I tap no vind—he won't inform— (to Barleycorn.)

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: I drinks vind, for I thirſts after the good things of this world.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: He's a wet Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Shall they take up dinner?

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: Yes, I hungers after good; I could munch one morcil of Portlin mutton; yea, one pound and an half, and ſix, and four, and two wheat ears, roaſted in wine leaves, and other ſettries of niceiſh ſaver.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: (Looking out.) The 'ſquire—dang my buttons, here'll be work.

div.stage: Enter WHIMMY, (looks at the broken Statues with amazement.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Fury and diſtraction! what's all here!—Tully! (calls.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.l: "They'd be like the Highlanders eating of kall,

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: This is your going to the alehouſe, here's your brags, here's yellow-breech'd bees humming their bag-pipes—but I'll turn over a new leaf, I'll dig and root out—

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p:
Arrah, Sir, I wiſh you'd let the leaves and the trees alone! you've been digging and rooting prettily:
what put it into your head to pull up the plants in this manner?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: My head, there's my dancing Faunus.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: Oh! I ſee how this is; you want to keep me only as your ſhow-man, and take the head gard'ning into your own hands—the geranums all torn, the myrtles, and lillies, and laylocks, are all pull'd about as if they were old bean ſtalks.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: You raſcal! what do you talk of your paltry plants—look at my ſtatues, none equal to them in the Barbarini gallery.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: The barber's gallery! Only tell a body what you intend to put down in the place—if yourſelf was planted, the devil a thing would grow out of your head but potatoe apples.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Two of my Seaſons—

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: You don't know the ſeaſons; you're a gentleman, and you've money to buy roots and fruits, but I tell you, you don't know an annual from an evergreen. I got myſelf finely laughed at to-day by ſhowing your kickſhaws, but I waſh my hands out of it. There's your deſcribing book (throws book down) and you may get another Ciceroni magpye to chatter to the company.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: There's a villain!

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Knock people's hats off—can't think who the fellow was!—Dick, I'm on the ſpur to fetch my nephew from Weymouth; an idle ſcoundrel! what perplexities he has involved me in! Dolts to apprehend Natty Maggs for him; theſe country conſtables are ſo obſtinate, won't even take my word: but what ſort of wild people have you ſettled amongſt here that pull folks heads about?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Yes, heads, legs, and arms, look! (points to the ſtatues.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: (Looking round.) Ha! ha! ha! a good deed however.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What, to demoliſh my beauties?

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Your modern gardens are art ſpoiling nature • fixing up a ſtone woman where one expects to find a roſy girl of health, fleſh, and blood: if we muſt have ſtatues, inſtead of importing ancient heathen gods into Engliſh meadow, why not encourage Britiſh arts to celebrate Britiſh heroes? for a Jupiter by Phidias give me an Elliot by a Bacon: the five thouſand pounds you laid out upon that clumſy Pantheon yonder, wou'd have built a neat cluſter of alms-houſes, where age and infancy might find an aſylum from the pangs of indigence.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, but Billy—

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: 'Sblood, when I reflect I owe my preſent independence to my education in the Blue Coat School, as I drive my whiſky on a Sunday by Dulwich College, I feel more warmth of affection for the memory of Edward the king, or Alleyn the player, than for all the travelling cognoſcenti in Chriſtendom. Dick, I love reaſon.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: A rare chace, but I got from him—zounds! (ſees Old Pranks, runs off.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Oh, damme, I'll have you, (purſues.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: He likes reaſon, and the fellow's mad; there he runs after my hermit. Certainly 'twas this ſavage old Goth committed theſe barbariſms—I hope he'll not find his nephew; however, I muſt prepare my daughter for the marriage.

div.head: SCENE III. Inſide of Hermitage. YOUNG PRANKS ſitting in his Hermit's Dreſs, as if put on haſtily.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p:
(Looking about.) I thought I had a glimpſe of him darting this way—Eh! one of Whimmy's toys
— (ſeeing Young Prauks) Father Dominick—ſeen a ſcoundrel run in here—Do ye hear! can you ſpeak!—it was certainly my nephew; a hound! ſkulking about, and ſuffer a poor innocent man to be taken up for him; to be handcuff'd, haul'd, and dragg'd—

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: An innocent man ſuffer for me! (throws off his hermit's dreſs.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: You! Oh you villain! How dare you borrow money about as you have done!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Sir, (confuſed) I—I—borrow'd money to get out of debt.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Eh! how?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, to pay my debts.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: But why get in debt?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: All owing to my good principle, the people wou'd truſt me, my character was ſo excellent.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Then from your excellent character they think you a damn'd rogue—you villain!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p:
Dear Sir, diſcriminate between vice and folly; you are the only one I ever wrong'd, my ſecond
parent, my friend, my benefactor. Sooner than let this perſon you ſpoke of juſt now any longer bear the diſgrace that I only deſerve, I'll inſtantly free him by delivering myſelf up to hopeleſs impriſonment, (going.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Eh! ſtop you rogue you, conſider how terrible a priſon is.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, no! the only difference between the people walking by and I is, that they're on one ſide of the door and I'm on t'other. A priſon! to reſign myſelf to it, now, is barely performing the duties of honeſty.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Surrenders to free the guiltleſs! Not ſo bad as I thought him.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Sir, I've been told, ſince you're a banker gentleman in Lombard-ſtreet, London, you bankers, Sir, have always a great deal of money.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I've heard of petticoat pads—a piſtol may come out here! Well, my dear, granting I have money, do you want any?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p:
Not myſelf, Sir; there's a young gentleman is taken up for debt, Sir; I thought it a pity he ſhould go to priſon, as he got out of it before, and
that, you know, Sir, is a ſign he doesn't like it; hard for a perſon to go where they can't be happy.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Upon my word this young lady reaſons exceeding pretty—Well, Miſs?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: And Sir, my aunt by mother's ſide, has left me three hundred pounds independent of my father, here are the papers, Sir, all about it, Sir, if you'd be ſo kind as to advance the money, and tranſact the buſineſs of releaſing the young gentleman with it, I'd be very much obliged to you, Sir, (curtſies.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Here's a charming girl! And ſo, my dear, you think Natty Maggs ſo fine a fellow, that you give up all your fortune to releaſe him.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Natty Maggs! No, Sir, our 'ſquire's hermit.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Hermit! She muſt mean my wild nephew, (overjoyed.)

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Sir, keep the papers, I know you'll free him; you look ſo good-natured, I beſeech you, Sir, Sir,

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p:
Tol lol lol, (ſings.) The heart of an amiable woman is the true touchſtone of manly merit. This good and delicate creature loves my nephew, and he muſt be a worthy lad. The girl, no matter for
her ſituation, is come of a good ſtock, and ſhould be tranſplanted. I didn't, till now, know my nephew—I'll forgive, I'll give him all—Go to the King's Bench again! that he ſhan't, while I've a guinea to keep him out of it, tol lol lol. Sings and exit.

div.head: SCENE IV. A Gallery in Whimmy's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter YOUNG PRANKS (haſtily croſſing) and PEREGRINE meeting, (much agitated.)

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Stop, Tom, whither now?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: To the King's Bench—what's the matter? Oh, true, Miſs Dian told me—upon my ſoul her father uſes you both very ill—who is this whelp he is going to give her to?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I don't know; Mr. Whimmy has never even ſeen him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: No! An uncle, isn't it that's bringing this about? I've a good uncle—but long before he'd think of providing me with an heireſs—but then I've been ſuch a curſed fellow.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p:
One chance, this ſpark may, as it's a forced thing, 〈◊〉 indifferent, and the old gentleman doats ſo upon
his daughter, that were an emperor to ſlight her, 'twou'd for ever loſe his favour.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: What's this uncle's name?—who, where, what is he?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I know nothing about him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Nor old Whimmy neither.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: I've never ſeen him, I told you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then I'll perſonate him, and I warrant you diſguſt the old gentleman ſufficiently to make him break off the match; then, Peregrine, is your harveſt, I'll be with you in a trice. Never be diſmay'd, Peregrine, when you admit me as a ſchemer into your cabinet; for I have turn'd my coat ſo often ſince I arriv'd in theſe parts, that there is no doubt of my being a moſt finiſhed politician.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: In vain talking, child;—I muſt keep my firſt promiſe.

sp.speaker: DIAN.
sp.p: But, dear Sir, will you ſentence your child to miſery?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Sir, you encourag'd me with a certainty that I ſhou'd be the happieſt of men, and now in a moment, to ſnatch me from Heaven, and plunge me into an abyſs of deſpair.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Can't help it, Dian;—I muſt give you to my friend's nephew.

sp.speaker: SKIP.
sp.p: Sir, here's a young gentleman will ſee you—ſeems in a piteous taking. Here's my maſter, Sir.

div.stage: Enter YOUNG PRANKS, diſguiſed like a boy, his hair pulled round his face, &c.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS,
sp.p: Oh! I will not have her.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! who are you?

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Certainly Tom Pranks. (To Dian.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: I don't want a wife. (Roars out crying.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Who the devil cares, whether you do or no—have you any buſineſs?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: No; I'm a gentleman. My uncle ſays I muſt marry your daughter; but I won't. (Roaring out.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! can this be the wild rogue I've heard ſo much of? why, your uncle told me you were another-gueſs being. Dian, this is your huſband.—How do you like him?

sp.speaker: DIAN,
sp.p: I fee this. Sir, if Mr. Peregrine can pardon me, ſince you've ſet your heart on't, I'm reſign'd to your will, with the dutiful obedience of a daughter.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Now, that's very lucky. Peregrine, you ſee—

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Then, Sir, ſince the lady is ſo very fickle, I reſign her with little regret.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Ah! this is all very well; then we'll call your uncle; Parſon Jack is in the next room, and you ſhall be married immediately.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: But I won't marry, oh! (cries)—I'll never ſay, father-in-law, to ſuch an ugly old fellow as you.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, you damn'd impudent young ſcoundrel, dare you affront me, and refuſe my daughter? then let your uncle do his worſt. There, Peregrine, take Dian, and may I be curs'd if ever I again attempt to part you.

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: You'll alter your mind again, Sir.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: I'll put that out of my power—go, Doctor, (calling off) tack that couple together inſtantly.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: My uncle! oh! zounds!

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Billy, what bouncing you've kept about this nephew of your's. He, a buck, and a blood!—a blubbering milkſop.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: My Tom a milkſop! I ſay he's a buck.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: I ſay he's an aſs. (Wrangling, Y. Pranks cries out.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: There's the buck! a taſteleſs hound, has been abuſing me here, and refuſed my daughter.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Oh! the devil! am I really the character I only perſonated. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Can't you ſee? thraſh him for his impudence to me.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Why, ah, Tom!

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Aye, poor Tom! (Snivelling.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: By the Lord, it's my galloping hermit! (ſurpris'd) and your nephew.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Sir, I now ſee your goodneſs; but had I even before known it, I cou'd not have enjoy'd the bleſſing you deſign'd for me, at the expence of a friend's happineſs. Mr. Peregrine has love and merit.—I admire, but don't deſerve the lady.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, ſince you're ſo diſintereſted as to decline the golden pippin, I'll give you a ſweet wild ſtrawberry.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: O Mr. Banker, have you—'tis he (looking at Young Pranks with joy) thanky, Sir. (Curtſies to Old Pranks.)

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Tom, here's a girl that wou'd have barter'd all her little fortune for your freedom; and now as you hope for mine, take her.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Why, ſhe's daughter to the Red Lion.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Aye, my honeſt landlord, that reliev'd the ſufferers, while you were ſwallowing peaches in December, and the poor ſhivering in cold and nakedneſs. Red Lion, Dick! where honour's derived from benevolence; ſhe's daughter to a nobleman. What ſay you, my girl?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Only, Sir, that my heart is fill'd with gratitude; but you muſt aſk the Red Lion's conſent; for tho' you were a huſband for a queen, I wou'd not have a prince, if it might grieve an indulgent parent.

div.stage: Enter TOBY and JOHN GRUM, with MAGGS, (his dreſs very much diſordered and torn.)

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Your worſhip, here's the defender is obſtropolos, and has lick'd I and John Grum.

sp.speaker: MAGGS.
sp.p: Aye, dem'me, I plump'd 'em.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Was't you, Natty? I'm ſorry that my irregularities ſhou'd have involv'd you in this trouble.

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Oh! Natty Maggs—my child to be haul'd and maul'd—but this comes of your denying me your honour'd mother.

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Haul'd and maul'd—may the ſon never get better uſage who cou'd deny his parent.

div.stage: Enter BARLEYCORN and TULLY, bringing in BAREBONES.

sp.speaker: BARLEYCORN.
sp.p: Dang my buttons, you ſhall—

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p:
Only this devout preacher walks into Mr. Barleycorn's and crams himſelf like a great fowl; then walks off without diſcharging his ſhot; when aſk'd, ſays he, you'll be paid above, and ſays Mr. Barleycorn, by who there? and ſays he, why by Abdiel; ſo they walk'd up ſtairs to me, where I was taking a pint and a whiff of tobacco. I was chriſten'd Mr. Tull •
▪ ſo I walks down—but who ever ſaw an angel with a pipe in his mouth? I don't mind paying for a man • dinner; but, Sir, be ſo kind as to ſend this geatleman to jall. How do ye do, Mrs. Maggs?

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: My Saint George's Fields landlord!

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: The ſpirit openeth my mouth.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: You opened your mouth to ſwallow a leg of lamb, honey.

sp.speaker: BAREBONES.
sp.p: All things ſhall be in common with the righteous?

sp.speaker: TOBY.
sp.p: Pay me for ſarving capias on Muſter Pranks.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Me! how?

sp.speaker: OLD PRANKS.
sp.p: Capias! What, you villain, are you that Ham Barebones that has lent my nephew money at an exorbitant uſance.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: That, like the devil, tempted me by the means, and now puniſhes me for the ſin.

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: Talk of righteouſneſs! and bilk the houſe of an honeſt induſtrious man. (Lays hold on Barebones.)

sp.speaker: PEREGRINE.
sp.p: Mrs. Peregrine (to Whimmy.)

sp.speaker: DIAN.
sp.p: Deareſt father, your bleſſing. (They kneel to Whimmy.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: There, my bleſſing on you both, you two ſouls. (Puts his hand on their heads.)

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, my dear uncle, I take my lovely Kitty Barleycorn, and whilſt her gentle qualities convince our friends, that birth and rank are not neceſſary to conſtitute an amiable wife, my reſpect for her virtues may prove, that the thoughtleſs prodigal can make a good huſband.

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Oh! I'm happy! ha! ha! ha! We've all got ſo very generous. Peregrine, with his little fortune, have Dian and all my wealth; your nephew, with your riches, takes little Kitty Barleycorn with nothing at all; and ecod, Mrs. Maggs looks ſo ſpruce, that I could find in my heart to— (going up to her.)

sp.speaker: MRS. MAGGS.
sp.p: Now that's ſo like Mr. Olmondle, (ſmiling and advancing.)

sp.speaker: WHIMMY.
sp.p: Oh! (runs from her.)

sp.speaker: TULLY.
sp.p: And now, Mrs. Maggs, you will be drinking the apricocks.

sp.speaker: YOUNG PRANKS.
sp.p: Then, Sir, ſhall we be merry. Here ends my ſeven years hermitage, and, inſtead of my annuity, I ſhall think myſelf nobly rewarded, if my extravagant tricks and fancies can, by an indulgent ſmile, receive the forgiveneſs of my generous friends.
